final_answer.precision_note: The concentration of NaOH (0.150 mol dm-3) has three significant figures, while the volumes (25.00 cm3 and 23.40 cm3) have four. The final result is limited by the least precise measurement, 0.150 mol dm-3, to three significant figures.

method: First, calculate the moles of $\text{NaOH}$ used in the titration. Convert the volume to $\text{dm}^3$: $23.40 \text{ cm}^3 / 1000 = 0.02340 \text{ dm}^3$. Then, $n(\text{NaOH}) = c \times V = 0.150 \text{ mol dm}^{-3} \times 0.02340 \text{ dm}^3 = 0.003510 \text{ mol}$. Second, use the stoichiometry from the balanced equation $\text{H}_2\text{SO}_4 + 2\text{NaOH} \rightarrow \text{Na}_2\text{SO}_4 + 2\text{H}_2\text{O}$ (a $1:2$ mole ratio) to find the moles of $\text{H}_2\text{SO}_4$: $n(\text{H}_2\text{SO}_4) = 0.003510 \text{ mol} / 2 = 0.001755 \text{ mol}$. Finally, calculate the concentration of $\text{H}_2\text{SO}_4$ using the volume $25.00 \text{ cm}^3$ ($0.02500 \text{ dm}^3$): $c(\text{H}_2\text{SO}_4) = n / V = 0.001755 \text{ mol} / 0.02500 \text{ dm}^3 = 0.0702 \text{ mol dm}^{-3}$.
checks: A quick check can be performed using the relationship (c_a * V_a) / n_a = (c_b * V_b) / n_b, where n_a=1 and n_b=2. c_a = (c_b * V_b * n_a) / (V_a * n_b) = (0.150 * 23.40 * 1) / (25.00 * 2) = 3.51 / 50.00 = 0.0702 mol dm-3. This confirms the calculation.
